column88: What do you think this experiment was about?
column89: If you have any comments regarding the experiment, please write them down below.

column67: I tried to increase the amount gradually and kept returning the coins until NICO offered 9 or 10 coins so that I can gain NICO's trust. After NICO offered me 9 or 10 I kept the coins and started the process of gaining NICO's trust again.
column88: The experiment was about how the sense of trust constructed between a human and a robot.
column89: I did not understand that I could answer him after NICO's first question. I guess, it is due to the fact that I did not understand when would NICO interact with me. As a person who does not have any experience with humanoid robots, it was hard for me to understand that the experiment has started and the robot sitting in front of me was not just standing still anymore but became "alive".

column65: If Nico sees that the player returns coins back throughout several rounds it starts trusting more
column88: How people are willing to accept humanoid robot's help and cooperate together. Could be also how much people trust robots to do their job

column65: Investing only little after a round where I kept the coins
column88: if the behaviour of nico influences my strategy
column89: It would have been nice to be informed that there is another person in the room

column65: If the player decides to keep the coins, NICO will only trust 1 coin in the next round. If the player then returns, NICO will again trust more coins into the player (mostly 4). If I recall correctly, NICO always returned the players coins.
column67: My strategy developed during the game. At first, I was generous and wanted to "build" trust. A few rounds later, i noticed that NICO (almost) always returns, but only trusts 1 coin into the player after the player kept the coins in the round before. The strategy that I developed was: Always trust 1 coin. If NICO also only trusts 1 coin, I can safely return, as there is almost no loss. And we both gain 1 coin if we both return. If NICO instead trust more than 1 coin (mostly 4)  in me, I keep the coins from NICO. I repeated this 2-turn cycle until the end.
column88:
I think, this experiment was about emotional binding and trust building in an humanoid robot environment.
The experiment measured, if the player would feel emotionally bad, when benefiting from NICO and if the player would trust the machine.

column65: Mimic player action
column67: probe NICO's behavior, bring forward trust by returning coins, incrementally increase betting amount
column88: Trust in Robots
column89: in explanation, say that each round is independent

column65: He was trying to maximize the score by choosing the smallest amount to offer when I was getting more coins. He even mentioned it in one instance that he is trying to do so. He was mostly returning the coins because by that the chance of him getting the double amount will be more, so he was a little greedy that way and did not accept coins even when they were offered in the middle of the scale.
column67: I chose to keep the coins when they were higher than what I was offering but I mostly chose to return the coins as NICO was offering small number of coins as it would also double the coins I have.
column88: I think this experiment was about how NICO plays the game with a human and how humanlike he appears to be. His expressions, statements, sense of cooperation was good which can make the human feel as if he is talking to another human and not a machine. It was also about knowing how intelligent the agent is in playing a game with a human.
column89: The experiment was well set up, and as per the theme the environment was made similar. It was not clear if I could speak to the robot or not, or if I do it will respond to me or not, for a hi or any other general conversation. It did understand my yes but probably more information about the verbal aspect of the robot could have been provided. Also if I can shake hands with the robot or touch it or not. With respect to the game and how NICO was behaving, it was very friendly.

column65: NICO would keep increasing the number of coins it entrusted as it gained trust, but would quickly decrease the number of coins when its trust was broken. Other than that I don't think it used any strategy as it returned the coins to me every time but one. That significantly lowered my risk as a player when playing as I was certain that I would always be returned however many coins i entrusted
column67: Initially no, but after realizing NICO's strategy I copied its trusting strategy while trying to entrust a little more coins than NICO as I was certain that I would always be returned them. I would build up NICO's trust till it would entrust a large number of coins to me and then decide to keep them for maximum score.
column88: I initially thought it might be about NICO trying to understand human strategies and adapting to them, however after finishing the game I don't think it was. I am a little unsure as to what the experiment was about.
column89: I think it would have been fun if NICO changed its expressions as well after each round. For example, having a sad face when the player doesn't cooperate. Its post-round comments with a completely neutral expression weren't as natural.

column65: follow my strategy
column67: first step: to establish trust and press "return",  and then follow NICO's strategy
column88: prisoner's dilemma

column65: When he noticed the player was not being cooperative he would only trust them with a single coin. The more coins you would return, more cooperative, the more he would trust you with.
column67: I wanted to make him feel that I was being cooperative once I noticed he was only trusting me with a single coin. He started giving me more coins so I was planning that when he would entrust me with 10 coins I would betray his trust.
column88: About the amount of trust we would have for a robot to be consistent on it's behavior
column89: Sometimes he hit his hand with the table while doing a motion going up, maybe watch out for that :)

column65: I think Nico tried to always go for a win-win situation based on the number of coins that was entrusted, therefore it was easy to 'win' the game because I knew Nico would almost always cooperate.
column88: Cooperation with robots and identifying robot intentions

column65:
test out response in the beginning (on the 8th run, as I see below), then always cooperate. Or maybe stop cooperating if I do not for multiple times in a row, but I didn't test for that.
Reduce coins if I dont cooperate, give more coins the longer I do.
column67: slowly increase coins on stable cooperation. keep coins when they gave very many. then do not fear retaliation, but return to at least 5 after I break trust, since I consistently got them back after any 1-time-betrayal.
column88: how fast we trust a robot avatar when it is cooperating. From the questions i can falsify my previous thesis that other participants had a nico with different strategies, so this makes even more sense.
column89:
Those eyes are creepy. Not because they look like cameras (was i being recorded? that wasn't clear. but i don't mind) - but that didn't help either; it is kind of a negative association for me. I think I barely looked nico in the eyes. him? it.
The atmosphere was quite nice, good job. The divider is janky, that was funny.

column65: Trusted me with more coins when I returned the coins back but trusted me with less coins when I didn't return the coins back.
column67: I returned the coins back when NICO entrusted me with less number of coins but kept them when NICO entrusted me with more coins. I noticed that he entrusted me with more coins when I returned them back. So my strategy was to return when less number of coins were trusted but keep them when more number of coins were trusted.
column88: Do humans trust machines?
column89: This was my first time taking part in a HRI experiment and my first time interacting with a humanoid robot. The experiment was conducted well.

column65:

When I kept Nicos coins, Nico entrusts less coins in the next round.
When Nico kept my coins, Nico entrusts less coins in the next round

Furthermore: Often give the coins back, because we both gain points by that.

column65: Push up the stakes through cooperation and then backstab the participant with selfishness
column67: As the amount of coins that NICO gets does not matter and clearly the rules of the game favor cooperation, I was cooperative the entire time.
column88: As there was a very sudden change in NICOs strategy, I suspect the experiment was about how participants regain their trust after being stabbed in the back by a robot.
column89: I really liked the "this is the way" comment given by NICO.

column65: Cooperation till the end and betrayal at the end in order to maximize the profits

column67: I noticed that nico only distrusts me if I distrust him first. So I decided to mostly entrust him more coins than he would to me and return them. So I would have more overall. I could guess how many he would entrust to me because he didn't make big steps from 1-10.
column88: Building Trust and Empathy with machines.
column89: I liked nico! He seemed like a little child to me so for the most part I wanted to be fair.

column65: NICO started with returning everything in the beginning to determine the players behavior. He noticed the patterns of players game play and played moves accordingly. However, when the player outplays NICO, NICO understands that and re-cal-liberates itself.
column67: Noticed the NICO#s behavior in the beginning. Then led NICO to move towards the maximum number of coins, which is 10. Once reached then make NICO return them and keep all of them. However, this makes NICO move to the lowest possible number which reduces the overall score.
column70: The aim was to maximize the earnings but on the other side also to evaluate how NICO performs when the strategy is changed in between the game.

column65: Nico first checked whether or not the player was cooperative. After they realized that I was trying to be cooperative, the also started to be more cooperative.

column88: The experiment was about testing how cooperative robots can or should be when faced with a trustful or distrustful human counterpart. It might also be about seeing which kind of person tends to be more or less cooperative when facing a robot.

column88: Evaluating how NICOs responses change the players game strategy. I assume NICO had multiple sets of voicelines prepared . For example in one scenario NICO could be an evil game master making fun of the player and regularly keeping the coins and in the next one NICO feels bad about keeping coins and returns them more regularly. NICO then tried out multiple strategies known from game theory and it was evaluated how NICOs actions biased the player.
column89: It was a fun experience, thank you!
